title: Can Bankruptcy Clear Civil Court Sanctions?
question: My former spouse is filing a motion for sanctions claiming they incurred 7k in debt because of my motion. If the Judge grants the other parties motion for sanctions, can I declare bankruptcy to erase any sanctions imposed against me? I've been unemployed because of serious medical conditions (stage 4 lukehemia).
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Lawsuits and disputes,Filing a lawsuit,Civil court
answers: It depends. As the first attorney mentioned, bankruptcy is for non - intentional items. You can make a pitch to have intentional items removed but it is difficult. You should talk to a BK attorney right away b/c filing for BK for a potential sanctions debt might not be smart. It all depends on your facts. Just b/c you are sanctioned does not automatically mean it is not dischargeable. However, if the Judge thinks you filed a motion without merit, you might be sanctioned. Regardless, Judges to not just sanction for the heck of it and very few sanctions, even when requested, are granted..

While bankruptcy can discharge a wide variety of debts, it generally can not be used to erase judgments based on intentional torts; criminal fines; punitive damages and likely a monetary sanction such as what you describe. However, and unless you personally know that you made a motion that was frivolous, in bad faith and/or made with the intent to cause embarrassment or prejudice to your adversary, it is within the court's discretion to grant such types of monetary sanctions. The mere fact of you having lost the motion, by itself, does not mean that they are automatically entitled to sanctions. It may be worth every penny to pay for one hour of a matrimonial attorney's time to sit down and go over the details. It is not wise to file for bankruptcy based on a [potential| 7,000.00 dollar debt.
